headline: CNN News Central
subHeadline: Now: Jury Deliberating In Trump Criminal Hush Money Trial; Zero-Down Mortgages Are Making A Comeback; Study: Possible Link Between Tattoos And Cancer. Aired 1:30-2p ET

utterances.speaker: LEON PANETTA, FORMER WHITE HOUSE CHIEF OF STAFF, CLINTON ADMINISTRATION
utterances.sentences: Obviously, you know, we can continue to proceed with our position.But we're going to have to pay close attention. You know, when you -- when you get into a situation in Rafah where your forces are there and they're confronting an enemy, it's oftentimes very difficult to put limits on how they approach fighting an enemy. And that really -- you know, that -- that really does involve a lot of risks here as to whether or not this red line is ultimately going to be crossed or not.

utterances.speaker: BRIANNA KEILAR, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes, this could snowball right across that red line as many people see it.Secretary, great to have you. Leon Panetta, thank you.

utterances.speaker: PANETTA
utterances.sentences: Good to be with you.

utterances.speaker: BORIS SANCHEZ, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: The jury in former President Donald Trump's historic criminal hush money trial is once again behind closed doors and deliberating. Earlier today, they reheard portions of the jury instructions.Here's what the reading of the instructions that Judge Juan Merchan covered: Reasonable doubt, how the law addresses the concept of an accomplice, in this case, Michael Cohen, the requirement to find the defendant guilty of falsifying business records in the first degree, definitions for enterprise, business record and intent as well. Joining us now is retired New York Criminal Court Judge George Grasso. He's been in court every day since the trial began. Judge, thanks so much for being with us. What's your take on the jurors asking for these instructions to be re- read?

utterances.speaker: GEORGE GRASSO, RETIRED JUDGE, QUEENS COUNTY SUPREME COURT
utterances.sentences: Great to be with you, Boris.Well, it shows me, number one, that this is a very serious jury. This jury really is taking their job - they're taking their job to heart. They want to -- they're not just diving in. And it's very unusual, frankly, in my experience that, on the first day of deliberations, which was yesterday, the jury sent a note out that they wanted to have such a wide swath of the judge's instructions re-read to them. That shows us that they are doing exactly what they should be doing in this case. They're going to dot the "I"s and cross the "T"s.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Does this make you more or less confident that this jury is going to be able to reach a unanimous verdict and not wind up a hung jury?

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: It actually makes me more confident that we're going to get a unanimous verdict in this case. Because they appear to be acting as a team.You know, one thing that I was able to do when the instructions were being read,  -- they were being read for about 40 minutes. Since I already took extensive notes of the instructions previously, yesterday, I spent the majority of that time carefully observing each juror. I was making a couple of notes about how I saw them. And in particular, I noticed the foreman, jury number one, juror number one, he was just so locked in, locked in in a way that I hadn't noticed him before. Every juror -- and I watched this very carefully from my vantage point inside the courtroom -- they were literally hanging on every one of the judge's words. It -- let me tell you, as a judge who has delivered instructions to jurors, you just don't see it like that so often. So very impressed. So this tells me they're starting in as a team. They're going to do this as a team. And I think they're going to work hard to come to verdict. But I wanted to hold my breath about hearing of them getting a verdict today or maybe even tomorrow. We may go into next week on this. I wouldn't be surprised.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: So, Judge, former President Trump falsely claimed that Judge Merchan is not requiring a unanimous verdict from this jury.A fact check, what he actually instructed them was that they -- they do have to agree that the defendant conspired to promote or prevent the election of any person to a public office by unlawful means. What they don't have to agree on is what those unlawful means were, right? They can choose from several different unlawful means. Would you have handled instructions in the same way? Do you think that leaves room for ambiguity among the jurors?

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Judge George Grasso, we very much appreciate you sharing your insights with us. Thanks.

utterances.speaker: GRASSO
utterances.sentences: Thank you, sir.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: One of the country's largest mortgage lenders is offering homebuyers the deal of a lifetime, zero down on your dream home. But the new program is making experts nervous about how these loans might backfire.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: And for some, it's bringing back some bad memories. Think 2008 financial crisis and the Great Recession.We have CNN's Matt Egan joining us now to explain. All right, tell us about this, Matt. How does the program work? Is there a catch? Are they going to be more judicious about who they give these loans to?

utterances.speaker: MATT EGAN, CNN REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Well, Boris and Brianna, we know a lot of people would love to buy right now, but they just don't have enough money for a down payment.And so this major mortgage lender is trying to come up with a solution by getting rid of the down payments all together. Now this comes from United Wholesale Mortgage. They've launched this 0 percent down payment mortgage program. Yes, 0 percent down. It's open to first-time homebuyers and lower-income borrowers. And essentially, it's two loans. The first one covers 97 percent of the value of the home. And the second one is the remaining 3 percent, up to $15,000. Now, experts are stressing that borrowers really have to read and understand the fine print here. Because the good news is that second loan, it's interest free, which is great. And there are no monthly payments. Now if there's a catch, it's the fact that that's second loan, it doesn't go away. It is due in full when the mortgage is paid off, refinanced or the home is sold. Now, the mortgage company told me that the demand for this 0 percent down mortgage is off the charts. They just launched it two weeks ago and they've already gotten thousands of applications.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: So, Matt, what more or experts saying about the parallels between this and 2008?

utterances.speaker: EGAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, 0 percent down, what could possibly go wrong, right?(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: EGAN
utterances.sentences: Listen, here's the issue. The issue is that the borrower is going to have no equity in the home at all. And home prices are at historic highs. So, sure, home prices continue to go up and up, but eventually, that may stop. And the problem is that if home prices actually go down, then theborrowers would instantly be underwater. Meaning they owe more than the home is actually worth. That's exactly what we saw during the subprime mortgage meltdown. So imagine a scenario where someone has to sell their home because they lose their job or they have to relocate, well, they still owe that second mortgage in full. And if they can't come up with the cash, well, they could face foreclosure, they could damage their credit. That's why Better Markets CEO Dennis Kelleher, he told me that this program has the potential to, quote, "turn the American dream of home ownership almost immediately into a nightmare." Now the company is pushing back, saying that this program is good for consumers and that critics are, quote, "uneducated about the current state of the industry." At the end of the day, Boris and Brianna, this is clearly a potential solution to the affordability problem. But it's just really important that borrowers understand what they're getting into because this is a solution that is not without risks.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: And just to be clear, you said that 3 percent loan, it maxes out at $15,000. Is that right?

utterances.speaker: EGAN
utterances.sentences: That's right, up to $15,000.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: All right. We'll continue to follow this. It's really interesting.Matt Egan, thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: And still to come, could there be a possible link between tattoos and a type of cancer? I know that's going to get the attention of a lot of people. So we're going to talk about this new warning from researchers, next.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: So one-third of all Americans have a tattoo, but a new study is raising concerns about their impact on your health.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: That's right. The research suggests a potential link between tattoos and an increased risk of malignant lymphoma -- pardon me -- lymphoma, which is a type of cancer that affects your lymphatic system.CNN health reporter, Jacqueline Howard, is here to break this down for us. And we should mention, Jacqueline, that some experts are skeptical. I think that's really important. Tell us what's happening here.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes. I hope that lower back tat I got back in spring break, '02, doesn't come back to bite me.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Jacqueline Howard, thank you so much. Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Might have to put off the show logo tat --(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: -- that we we're talking about getting, right?

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: Delay that.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Let's delay it until we get some --

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: More information, we need that.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes. Turning now to a wild story. This, you have to see. A judge in Michigan was stunned after a man accused of driving on a suspended license made a virtual court appearance while driving.Watch this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED JUDGE
utterances.sentences: Are you driving?

utterances.speaker: CORY HARRIS, DEFENDANT
utterances.sentences: Actually, I'm pulling into my doctor's office.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED JUDGE
utterances.sentences: This is a driving while license suspended?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: That is correct, Your Honor.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED JUDGE
utterances.sentences: He doesn't have a license, he's suspended, and he's just driving.The defendant needs to turn himself into the Washington County Jail by 6:00 p.m. today. Failure to turn himself in will result in a bench warrant with no bond.

utterances.speaker: HARRIS
utterances.sentences: Oh, my god.(END VIDEO CLIP) (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: What were you expecting, my friend?All right. So as you heard, the judge there revoked Cory Harris' bond, ordered him to turn himself in to a local county jail the same day. CNN has reached out to his lawyer for comment but has not yet heard back about what is really turning into a viral moment.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: You didn't see you it in the video, but there's a moment where the judge is looking at people in the courtroom --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: -- like is this real life? Is this actually happening?

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: It is real life, Judge.

utterances.speaker: SANCHEZ
utterances.sentences: Ah.

utterances.speaker: KEILAR
utterances.sentences: He did not get that at all.(LAUGHTER
